Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2008 04:59AM 12954 wrote: Carol  The various picture will indicate "something', but often until the "something" is examined under a microscope they don't know for sure. I found that often drs are reluctant to speculate until they are very sure. In my case the radiologist who read the mammogram was very good at showing me the calcifications and explaining briefly why they would need a biopsy. When I went to the surgeon, she was way  more evasive- we won't know until we biopsy- etc. I think many drs are worried about offering a speculation and then being wrong, or maybe it could be a couple of possibilities.  After you get the pathology report you will get the same sort of info people here have- or maybe it will be nothing. trish
Posts.Title: Is this the norm Carol315 lvtwoqlt

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2008 05:48PM 12954 wrote: The mammogram will probably be done first. They will have you come back and undress from the waist up and put on a robe. The technician will take you into a room with the machine. She will probably give you a small sticker to place where you felt the lumb. The will give you 2 small stickers with metal dots on them to cover your nipples. Then the technician will have you stand up next to the machine. Your breast is place on the lower plate of the machine. The top plate lowers down compressing the breast and an xray is taken. They reposition you a number of times. Usually a radiolist will look at it and if they see something, they may bring you back for more pictures. I found it uncomfortable more than painful. I am quite small so the position were very awkward, but it is quick. The ultrasound is completley painless and easy. You lie down. The tech puts some gel on your breast then rubs a probe? over them. The views are on a screen. It is the same type of ultrasound they use when you are pregnant.  Normally you just have a mammogram, but if they think there is something ( and you have a lump) then an ultrasound is a pretty normal screening tool. The ultrasound is good at identifying cysts- which are normally quite harmless and quite common. Try not to worry any more than you have to until you have some results, as everyone says a high percent of these are benign. Trish
Posts.Title: My doctor's appt........ rlb3271973 lvtwoqlt

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2009 04:58AM - edited Jun 29, 2009 04:59AM by 12954 Mari  Some indecision ( or worry) is just about inevitable- a year and a half after my unilateral, I am comfortable with my decision ( no recon ). I know I made the right decision for me at the time. I find now that I rarely wear a prothesis, but I have one I can if I need to. I too was not up to all the additional surgery recon would require. I wanted minimal medical intervention.  I'm not sure what the future will bring-- if the other side has a problem, maybe I will talk to a PS, likewise if I someday decide I'm not happy the way  I am I know there may be  options. Sure, I would rather have avoided this whole thing, but what happened did and I made the best decision I could and moved forward. The recovery was not bad, particularly since I didn't have a SNB. I din't get any "rules" or even suggestions from my doctor for post surgery, but I did use alot of common sense and took things slowly. I was lucky my drains came out right away. There was discomfort after the surgery, but not a lot of strong pain. It sounds like you made the decision that fits you. Trish

Posts.Title: March 2008 Rads Team brst26 juliajo

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2008 02:43PM 12954 wrote: Skin coloring alone won't necessarily determine your reaction. I am a typical fair-skinned Irish person- summers meant my freckles melded together and I burned and peeled, but my reaction was not nearly as bad as many others here and because they used a bolus I was warned it might be very bad. I was careful with the lotions ( used them liberally) but there are clearly other factors involved. Good luck and Nan I think you have the right idea- get some cheap tshirts and bras that you can throw out after treatments are done- the grease from the gels and creams does not come out. Trish
Posts.Title: March 2008 Rads Team brst26 juliajo

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2008 12:02AM - edited Aug 14, 2008 09:01PM by 12954 Sue  Don't worry about your trip. If you see the surgeon the 15th he/she will likely want either more tests or a biopsy. Different places have different scheduling, but it would be fairly common to have to wait until the first of September anyway.( Heck the first surgeon I went to it was at least a 2 week wait to get in to see her) Then all the tests took at least that long to get appointments ( MRI, etc.)  You can have your appointments, get things set up and then enjoy your family. Disney with a large group may be just the place to distract you. Don't forget that even though they they have found Atypical cells it does not mean you have cancer. Many of us were suprised how long it often takes from the initial biopsy until surgery or treatments Enjoy your trip
Posts.Title: Waiting, Frustrated, and Worried SueMomOf2 SueMomOf2

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2010 02:58PM 12954 wrote: Hi I had a single mx 2 years ago. I dutifully went to the mast shop right after my surgery ( at my 1 week post surgery visit  my surgeon said I was ready to go)  I got  the form; took another year to find a mast bra that fit - used the form inside a regular bra before that. Now  though, I find I wear neither. I find the form awkward and I just don;t wear it anymore. There are one or two times a year when I get dressed up and feel I need it, but otherwise it stays in the box in my drawer. I did purchase a small foam exercise form online ( way cheaper than at the shop), but I don't even bother with that anymore. I don't think anyone even notices- it helps that I am small busted. If you still feel like returning it do so. You may be just as comfortable without and feel better about the money. There are cheaper foam alternatives if all you want to do is fill the top of a particular outfit. While the forms help many to feel more comfortable and "normal"- not everybody does. Do what seems right for you Trish

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2008 01:32AM 12954 wrote: Actually Sue- the dense breast tissue might be because you are not old enough. The denser breast tissue is one reason why mamogram aren't as routine for younger women. Glad you are scheduled for the biopsy.It should still be outpatient. Enjoy your trip Trish
Posts.Title: Waiting, Frustrated, and Worried SueMomOf2 SueMomOf2

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2008 06:57AM 12954 wrote: newmom  I know it is so easy to panic, but try not to assume the worst. The normal treatment for DCIS is a lumpectomy usually followed by radiation. If the DCIS is estrogen + (er+) Tamoxifen will often be recommended for 5 years. Other drugs sometimes if you are past menopause. A masectomy is usually only required if the dcis is spread throughout the breast: is extremely large: or if the women is small breasted and the lumpectomy would not leave much. There are some women who choose a mastecomty for peace of mind, but that is often a choice. The majority of people wiith dcis are successfully treated- no chemo, and most don't need mastectomy. I hope for your peace of mind you get results soon .

The pad they use for me is thick, plastic covered and  with strong chemical smell( apparently it is odd that the smell bothers me so much) I was warned that when they use the bolus it irrates the skin even more and that that was intended. I don't know if the warm cloth is for the same thing Trish

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2008 05:51PM - edited Mar 6, 2008 05:55PM by 12954 Luv 28 treatments- no boostd apparently not usually done with masectomies( I know yours does) no bloodwork ever with mine. I"m just as glad- they wouldn't have done it there and it would have meant another appointment- I've had enough. Aquaphor again at night before bed once in a while in the morning too. I was just lucky I guess. I'm typical fair skinned Irish lots of freckles, burn and peel skin. It's red and I did have a sun posioning like reaction on my chest ( bathing suit v area- not rads area). My celebration was limited to stopping for an ice coffee on the way home. I did get a bath and bodyworks gift card for Christmas that I think I will spend this weekend- something fragrant and non-white. ( I've already started back with deodorant- yay) kajo- my local walmart has aloe ( target only had with alcohol) if they don't work you can get it on amazon. Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2008 05:46PM - edited Jan 29, 2008 05:47PM by 12954 Doe If the tatoos were brown, they'd never find mine: they be hidden amongst the freckles. Then after simulation ( the 2nd try at it) they gave me more- these were much bigger- definitely highly visible. Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2008 11:58AM 12954 wrote: June  Your experience seems worse than most. I had the mock-up where they made the mold and took measurements- not bad 45 minutes or so. The sim was not as fun. I had a different tech for that. She put my arms in a slightly different position and kept telling me not to move. She tried to adjust to get the marks right and constantly said "don't help me" In the end they could't get anything to line up right. Told me I was breathing too deeply- how the hell am I not supposed to breathe at all I'm holding my arms in the air tight for 50 mins. They got real annoyed and eventually sent me home- rescheduled for 4 days later. Different techs that time- they were in a better mode. They added a pillow to the edge of the mold so that my arm had some support. It still took 40+ mins but was much less stressful. They use tatoos- only the one high on my chest is a sticker. The tech explained that the dr is adamant about using a sticker there because it will show even after radiation if it is a tatoo. The first set of tatoos were small and blended into my many freckles- the second set are definitely highly visible. When it looked like everything  was lining up they called in the doseimetrist(sp?). She verified a few measurements and left. After each xray they would run off to see the radiologist. The first day when it didn't work she  came in at the end and sent me home. Again you must be nervous you are breathing deeply. The second day she wasn't there, but the other guy in the group checked off on the xrays- he didn't come in. I ended up starting on Monday ( 3-4 days later than planned) they took pictures on Friday. Said will do them every 5-7 days. It only added about 10 minutes to the treatment. The whole thing usually takes about 10 minutes normally.( still long enough for my arms to go numb and me to get dizzy getting up everytime) They haven't said anything about lotions- it was in a handout they gave me before starting- Use any lotion you want just not before treatment.No deodorant and only shave with electric razor ( I'm ignoring that one and I do use the crystal deodorant. I don't ask) They weren't panicy about the sticker and I have put lotion over the whole area. If it falls off it falls off- I am using lotion liberally before I have a problem I'm noticing dryness on both sides but then it is winter and dry skin is a problem. The one thing I have consistently notice is an attempt to presereve whatever dignity they can. When they made the mold- the tech brought in a blanket to cover me "so I didn't get cold". The dr made sure the door was closed. When the do the treatments they line everything up then cover my one breast with a cloth. Hope things get better for you Trish

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2008 05:10PM 12954 wrote: Ulla  I have sensitive skin and am very prone to sunburns but so far I am doing pretty well ( 15 of 25 treatments done) I put lotion or aloe on after treatment( when I get home) and again at night before bed. Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2008 06:44PM - edited Feb 19, 2008 06:45PM by 12954 Dove has a nice "sensitive skin" liquid soap. I was told mild soap- no concerns about fragrances except if it irratates stop using it. I have had pain all along the arm- it feels like muscle pulls/ strain/soreness. The nurse suggested that it may be the arm position. while I'll buy that the arm position is aggravating it I can't believe it is causing it.   It feels sore deeper rather than just on the skin. Not sure if it is radiation or still scar tissue forming from the surgery. I have had some recent shooting pains- but I was warned about them.  I found the natural crystal deodorant in my grocery store ( I had looked it up on amazon so I recognized it) It sort of works. Because I am trying not to wear a bra ( which means no prothesis) I tend to wear more layers- so more sweating. I am now a bright pink in the radiated area with a contact dermatitis rash higher up on my chest. I'm saving the cortaid for when the itch gets really bad. Ulla I hope it gets better for you. I have 17/25 treatments done. Trish Bailey my local Walmart has aloe without alcohol and minimal dyes and fragrances.
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2008 06:20PM 12954 wrote: Sue My two oldest girls are 22 and 20 ( also have a 13 year old- a very 13 yr old) and a son about to turn 19. I too had "sun posioning" not in the rads area, but adjacent- where I have actually had sun poisoning and sunburns. I don't think that's unusual. It is somewhere between strong contact dermatitis and sun poisioning- it itches but if you scratch it hurts. My is not too bad. I am more sore today ( the day after rads than I was during most of the treatments,but then sunday and monday were usually the redest and sorest during treatment Quinnie- I am definitely different than many- I don't feel bad at all about not going anymore absolutely no mixed feelings- Drs appointment don't make me feel any more secure. I prefer not to go unless I am sick and need to see someone. I am usually positive, but I felt through the whole thing that I was doing rads because I needed to- the odds for recurrence were way to high for me, but in the end it may come back on the other side anyway. You work to reduce your odds, but ultimately it is a crap shoot. If it is meant to happen it will and if it does I'll deal with it. Hopefully it won't, but I can't and won't let it control my life ( and yes it has felt like it has at times)  Ready to move on ( or maybe return back to normal-soon) Disney should be fun- I'm heading to CA spring break to visit my oldest. The break will be wonderful and I aim to wear scoopnecks and no sweaters Trish

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2009 09:59AM 12954 wrote: I had no activity restrictions- just to keep the area dry ( 1 or 3 days different instructions after 2 biopsies) and to only use tylenol.They may suggest limiting to 10 lbs for 2 or 3 days. Posts.Title: Activity after Stereotactic biopsy pmb0602 pkb143

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2008 03:45AM 12954 wrote: Ins2119  The wire guided procedure is more weird than painful. With the size that small they need the wire for the surgeon to "see" the mass. You start with a mammogram- then once the area is clearly identifies they give you a shot to numb the area then insert a needle into the area. The radiologist verifies that they have corrrectly marked the area and the needle is withdrawn leaving behind a wire. The ends are taped off ( in my case covered with a paper cup- very attractive) and you are ready for them to remove the mass. As everyone else will tell you - get a copy of your pathology report when it is all done. Good luck. As to time- depending on scheduling it akes 1/2 to a whole day but you can return to work the next day. Trish

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2008 08:53PM 12954 wrote: Debi  They may or may not be benign. The biopsy is the only way to know for sure. While you may be lucky and have it be nothing (drs have been known to be wrong at times) I would probably be prepared for the possibility that it is DCIS ( but not the certainty- you don't know for sure). The lump may be related or totally unrelated- it sounds like they are more concerned about the calcifications. Why not ask the surgeon when you meet her/him or Wednesday. Start writing down your questions now. You will almost certainly have a biopsy- again what type is the next question for the surgeon. Good luck Trish

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2008 01:19PM 12954 wrote: Just had right side with no recon Where I live an overnight is the norm- other places it is strictly outpatient. If you don't have a node removed it is relatively simple surgery- no muscles are affected. I was told I could return to work 3 or 4 days after. I didn't - I teach and scheduled it just before Christmas so I could have more time. I had surgery on Wed, went home on Thursday, had the drain removed Friday. I was functional on Thursday- made dinner, rested, did light stuff around the house. I didn't need a lot of pain pills, but did use some when I returned to work the first few days. Recovery wasn't bad. One month later- it's still twitchy and occasionally sore- skin tenderness etc, but not all that bad overall
Posts.Title: Having a 2nd mast RJ62 12954

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2008 08:09AM 12954 wrote: Therese  I had a wire guided excisional last fall- no clip, but a stereotatic yesterday- had a clip left behind. Apparently it is quite normal to leave a clip when they do a stereotatic biopsy. I think that if they find something they can go right to the clip rather than having you go to radiology and have a wire inserted to let them find the location.  I know the radiologist is right lots of people have these clips in them. Even if the day was impossibly long thanks goodness he fit you in. I would much rather have all the tests over and done rather than stretched out even longer than you've already waited. Trish

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2008 07:29AM 12954 wrote: Otter I completely understand your problem. I also "shocked" my surgeon by asking for a mast rather than a lumpectomy. I am also very small and knew that even my small amount of dcis would mean removal of a significant chunk of my breast. If that was all it would have been fine, but keeping that small amount of tissue would mean 7 weeks of radiation and 5 years of tamoxifen. For me that was too high a price for a small amount of tissue. Radiation and hormone theraphy for me was more invasive than removal of my breast.  For others the loss of a breast would be more of a problem, but when you have always been a A or AA, very little of your self image is based on breast size. I did not want radiation and I did not want multiple surgeries for reexcisions. My gut kept saying mastecomy, but it was not an easy decision to come too. In the end it would have been necessary anyway. There was not enough tissue to ever have gotten an acceptable margin and I had a small amount of dcis. Unfortunately I still have to do the radiation as the tumor was on the chest wall. My only suggestion is that if you are  even considering radiation- talk to a ps before the surgery. I opted not too- thinking that if I ever want to I can deal with it later, however the radiation  now limits my choices ( prob never would anyway). Make your own decision. If you feel uneasy go with the lumpectomy, but if you keep coming back to thinking a mastectomy is best- do that. I suspect many have a fleeting thought of just take them off- however that is different from someone who keeps coming back to "this makes more sense for me"  I also will add it was helpful to hear from others that I wasn't crazy or overreacting ( how the dr made me feel)

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2008 04:42PM 12954 wrote: Yes Candy tx is shorthand for treatment. Er and Pr are estrogen and progestron. Your tumor may have been tested to see if it was ER+ or ER-, likewise for PR. Her is another test that is sometimes done. I have dcis so it isn't done for that type of cancer. If your tumors are ER/PR positive tamoxifen is often considered as a treatment or preventative. If you are HER+ there are certain drugs that are used to treat it. Before you get the radiation there will be one or more sessions to take pictures and measurements to make sure the xrays hit the precise right spot. Those are simulations ( you don't get zapped then) You will  likely get tatoos during one of these sessions

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2008 03:52PM 12954 wrote: Hi  Sorry for your diagnosis. It is overwhelming initially. The tab up on the top of the forum  labeled symptom and diagnosis has a nice description of standard treatment. Generally, and there are exceptions, you'll see a surgeon first for lumpectomy, then a  oncology radiologist if you need radiation. The third peice for many is tamoxifen or an AI if you are postmenopausal. Some people see an oncologist for that, others their brest surgeon. Trish

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2008 09:13AM 12954 wrote: Angie  Usually it ends with the mascetomy. Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2008 10:57PM 12954 wrote: Try as hard as possible not to assume the worst until you have results. Just because they want more tests does not mean she has cancer. Trish
